title: DOSE3: Diffusion-Based Out-of-Distribution Detection on SE(3) Trajectories
author: Hongzhe Cheng (Robotics Institute Carnegie Mellon University), Tianyou Zheng (Robotics Institute Carnegie Mellon University), Tianyi Zhang (Robotics Institute Carnegie Mellon University), Matthew Johnson-Roberson (Robotics Institute Carnegie Mellon University), Weiming Zhi (Robotics Institute Carnegie Mellon University), ...
relevance_why: This paper introduces a novel approach for out-of-distribution detection using SE(3), which could be applicable in audio and robotics domains, particularly in tasks involving spatial transformations.
background: Out-of-distribution detection is a machine learning task that identifies samples deviating from expected distributions, particularly important for applications like robotics and autonomous driving where identifying abnormal behaviors can prevent failures.
contribution: DOSE3 introduces a unified diffusion framework specifically designed for detecting out-of-distribution trajectories in SE(3), achieving superior performance compared to existing OOD detection frameworks.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods primarily operate in Euclidean spaces, often requiring retraining for different datasets, which is computationally expensive.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work employs a unified diffusion model that incorporates manifold structures to effectively handle SE(3) transformations without the need for retraining.

key_innovation: Innovatively integrates manifold-specific diffusion processes with a unique architectural approach tailored to handle ordered sequences of pose data in three-dimensional space.
real_world_impact: The proposed method has significant implications for safety-critical applications in robotics by enhancing the capability to identify and respond to abnormal movement patterns in real time.
limitations: No explicit limitations are mentioned by the authors.

new_terms.SE(3): **Special Euclidean Group in 3D** is a mathematical group representing rigid body transformations, including rotations and translations in three-dimensional space.
new_terms.OOD: **Out-Of-Distribution** detection refers to the task of identifying when a data sample diverges from the expected distribution, a critical aspect in ensuring robust machine learning performance.
